title.value: On the Limitations of the Elo, Real-World Games are Transitive, not Additive
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the very beginning of the provided text.
title.quote: On the Limitations of the Elo, Real-World Games are Transitive, not Additive

extractions.description: The paper investigates the limitations of the Elo score in ranking players in competitive games by identifying the transitive components in real-world games. The study proposes an alternative ranking system that improves prediction performance in transitive games.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical validation of the proposed ranking system on real-world game payoff matrices.
type.quote: Finally, we conduct an in-depth empirical validation on real-world game payoff matrices: it shows significant prediction performance improvements compared to the Elo score.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on evaluating and ranking players in competitive games, which falls under the domain of game theory.
name.quote: The Elo score has been extensively used to rank players by their skill or strength in competitive games such as chess, go, or StarCraft II.

name.justification: The paper discusses multi-agent reinforcement learning and evaluation of agents in complex environments, a core topic in Multi-Agent Systems.
name.quote: More recently, a surge of interest in evaluation and ranking for games has been triggered by the successes of multi-agent reinforcement learning agents in increasingly complex environments.

name.justification: The paper mentions the application of reinforcement learning in the context of evaluating agents and designing learning algorithms for games.
name.quote: Thus, having accurate and scalable ways to evaluate agents becomes crucial to monitoring agents’ learning, selecting the best agents, and performing evolutionary algorithms.

name.justification: The Elo score is the primary existing model discussed throughout the paper as having limitations in evaluating the transitive component in games.
name.quote: The Elo score has been extensively used to rank players by their skill or strength in competitive games such as chess, go, or StarCraft II.
